Author: Audo#5667
Content:
Hey, we got a question about how long the bans last. Technically bans are permanent and we have to manually unban people. We are not too eager to unban the banned without being sure that they really want to come back to our community.

The solution is a form they can fill and make an appeal. If they do that and promise to behave we are happy to unban them.

The form: https://forms.monday.com/forms/5fd66a8253ca0111449a26807c88a113

 - Komodo community moderatorion team

Author: Audo#5667
Content:
hey @joe2x4 & @siu - Chainmakers we can continue the pricing discussion here.

The pricing we have is like a discovery pricing. We might tweak it in the future.

For dPoW we have used the concept of grandfathering of pricing concept where we keep charging the same amount that the project signed-up with. Thus even if we raise the price later it doesn't affect the current projects who operate with certain price tag in mind.

Author: joe2x4#5987
Content:
```there is some bashing going on to kmd because there is a fee for using antara network gui and atomicdex gui listing.```
 
 this is interesting. I'm curious to know where the current pricing came from. The people complaining probably won't bite even if the price is $6500 or $4500. Probably not even at $1000. These people are just not interested at any price. For those truly interested you could probably raise the price to $10,000-$20,000 and still get just as many bites. (Has anyone done a focus group on the pricing?) The weird thing about pricing and perceived value is if you price to low, people perceive low quality. I'd price Antara at $100,000 just like a CEX listing. Those that can pay, you want, those that can't, probably won't at any price anyway. But the perceived value is alot more serious then a good bargain. We don't want to be seen as needing to beg people to buy.
 You can also always lower prices through sales, discounts, grants, student discounts, scholarship, etc. Encourage people to run through the tutorial to get a discount or do x for discount. Or offer one month a year for a sale etc. What do the sales and marketing people have to say about this? @siu - Chainmakers

Author: Audo#5667
Content:
and I want to stress that

our atomic swap protocol & P2P orderbooks = decentralized open source technology without any listing pricing
AtomicDEX = a reference product build on top of this technology that is currently at least partly a propreatiery product that charges a listing fee (part of our business model)

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: ğŸ‘†ğŸ½ hence why I said you can fork it; the "listing" fee is from the GUI maker, not the actual network

Author: joe2x4#5987
Content: https://www.psychotactics.com/higher-prices-work/

Author: joe2x4#5987
Content: ```You may think having a cheaper product may get you a bigger slice of the market, but the moment your customers find that the competition is selling their bats at 30-50% higher than your price, you're in big doo-doo.```

Author: joe2x4#5987
Content: ```A customer will buy an expensive product or service not because they like blowing up money, but because it brings greater value```

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content:
that's where marketing comes in
"simply" show the consumers why your cheaper product is better or equal

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: shatter the myths

Author: joe2x4#5987
Content: Or simply raise prices and no need to educate as product is instantly better or the best. Prices can always come down.

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content:
fwiw:
There's a reason that Walmart makes a gajillion dollars a year on "Equate" brand products

Author: joe2x4#5987
Content: Many years ago, one of our clients, (we were their IT), was the highest priced plumbing service in the Denver area. The owner laid out this exact advise. He was VERY successful despite much cheaper options for plumbing. People wanted the best and perceived high price as "the best". I don't go to Walmart for the best.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
Nice summary:  GUI maker charges a fee.
1.  The initial research to integrate a GUI
2. The initial designs of the GUI
3. The ongoing maintenance of the GUI
4. The ongoing maintenance of the coins on the network used in the GUI
5. Also I think there are a couple of servers chucked in for keeping a running marketmaker for the coin.

(5) Itself is worth the fee alone in some industries

Author: willofleo#7505
Content: add to the assumption that antara will make it very easy for individuals to create their own coins , my only con about the charging fee is that which comes first, the coins or the volume , in all successful exchanges (although some failed after)  listed a-lot of coins for free and as they gained (or faked)volume started charging to gain access to the volume , so I think it volume first fees later , not the other way round to create a profitable GUI

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: If anyone thinks that it is easy or cheap to hire good devs to build out a GUI, they are kidding themselves.

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: I don't really like people using hyperDEX as a example of something free and kinda working as a argument for not paying a listing fee. It was not free, the bill was just footed by someone else. I cannot fault others from recouping some development costs to implement your project.

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: Realistically it would be hard to make back all the sunk costs of a GUI development with trading fees alone. You need to have trading volumes in the millions DAILY to make anything and 10s of millions to support more than 1-2 devs.

Author: siu - Chainmakers#3920
Content: True that
